description.en: The course will draw attention to the essence, principles and definitions of international crimes, as well as to various possibilities to handle them on international or internal level. Special attention will be drawn to definitions and procedural aspects of international crimes in Estonia.
description.et: Vaadeldakse rahvusvaheliste kuritegude olemust, põhimõtteid ja kuriteokoosseise, samuti rahvusvaheliste kuritegude menetlemise võimalusi rahvusvahelisel ja ka siseriiklikul tasandil. Eraldi tähelepanu pööratakse rahvusvaheliste kuritegude koosseisudele ja menetluslikele aspektidele Eestis.

objectives.en: To give an overview of the progressively developing discipline of international criminal law: to introduce students with respective international instruments, court practice and academic writings. To teach students to see and analyze the theoretical and practical issues of international criminal law
objectives.et: Anda ülevaade progresseeruvalt arenevast õigusharust - rahvusvahelisest kriminaalõigusest: viia üliõpilased kurssi asjakohase rahvusvahelise normatiivmaterjali, kohtupraktika ja erialakirjandusega. Õpetada nägema ja analüüsima rahvusvahelise kriminaalõiguse teoreetilisi ja praktilisi probleeme.

learning_outcomes.en: By the end of the course students have to:
- be able to explain the principles and fundamental concepts of international criminal law;
learning_outcomes.et: - võimeline selgitama rahvusvahelise kriminaalõiguse põhimõtteid ja põhimõisteid;

learning_outcomes.en: - be aware of topical issues of international criminal law and be able to discuss them;
learning_outcomes.et: - teadlik rahvusvahelise kriminaalõiguse aktuaalsetest probleemidest ja suutma nende üle arutleda;

learning_outcomes.en: - be able to orientate in the relevant institutions and instruments
learning_outcomes.et: - võimeline orienteeruma rahvusvahelise kriminaalõiguse olulistes institutsioonides ja normatiivdokumentides

independent_work.et:
*	Independent work with study materials
*	Self-testing exercises in Moodle 
*	Solution of mini-cases in Moodle
The solutions should be submitted electronically as a Word-file no later than on Sunday of the week of respective class at 12:00 (noon) via Moodle. Any solutions which are late are not accepted. Solutions sent by email are not accepted.
*	Writing an essay
In the essay, the student analyses critically one legal problem in international criminal law. The selected problem should be registered via Moodle no later than on the day of last lecture. The instructor may ask the student to choose another problem if the chosen problem is not suitable or too many students have already chosen the same problem. The paper should be submitted electronically as a Word-file no later than on by 1 December. For every started overdue day, the result will be decreased by 5 points, but papers which are late more than four days are not accepted and the student may not take the exam. Papers sent by email are not accepted.
The length of the essay main text should be min 2500 words. Shorter papers are not accepted or the result is lowered by the discretion of the instructor.
Independent identification of clear issues and legal problems is essential. Also, the use of different sources and supportive materials. All used sources must be referred to. In case of internet sources, the full address is necessary, not only the main domain (e.g. www.un.org). A paper based on copy-paste method leads to negative results for both the paper and the exam. Plagiarism is not tolerated at the University of Tartu.

grade_preconditions.et:
*	Participation in at least 9 colloquia. If a student misses a colloquium, he/she must submit, within a week, a 500 word long annotation of the topic discussed in the class.
*	Timely solution of mini cases in Moodle
*	Timely submission and positive evaluation of an essay.

grade_evaluation.et:
*	Exam-case max 100 points - 60% of the final grade
*	Essay max 100 points - 40% of the final grade

Criteria
*	Consistency, completeness and correctness of the solutions
*	Creativeness of the solutions 
*	Depth of the analysis of problems and applicable norms and principles
*	Association of theory with court practice
*	Structure, grammar and formatting

Grades (Cases)
A	Solution are remarkable; the examination of facts is full and logical; the analysis of legal problems is detailed and innovative; all relevant norms and principles have been used; the references to relevant court practice are thoughtful and creative; the form is excellent; overall, the text is a remarkable achievement [91-100 points]
B	Solution is very good with insignificant mistakes or omissions; the examination of facts is purposeful; the analysis of legal problems is very good with insignificant deficiencies; necessary norms and principles have been used; the references to court practice support the conclusions; the form is very good; overall, the treatment of the subject is logical and smooth [81-90 points]
C	Solution is good, but there are mistakes or omissions; the examination of facts addresses correctly the central issues; the analysis of legal problems is good with some deficiencies concerning specific issues; key norms and principles have been used; the form is good; overall, the coverage of the subject is logical, but there are some weaknesses from the point of view of the whole [71-80 points]
D	Solution is fair, but there are several mistakes or omissions; the examination of facts is satisfactory, but focuses only on the central aspects; the analysis of legal problems is satisfactory with deficiencies is most aspects; only basic norms and principles have been used; the form is fair; overall, the treatment of the subject is plausible, but insecure [61-70 points]
E	Solution is poor with significant mistakes (51-60 points)

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)

description.et: I INTRODUCTION, HISTORY, CONCEPT OF ICL, SOURCES, DELIMITATION
II PRINCIPLES, GENERAL PART: MISTAKE, INTENT, COMPLICITY, INCHOATE FORMS OF CRIME
III GENERAL PART: DURESS, SUPERIOR ORDERS RESPONSIBILITY OF SUPERIOR
V SPECIAL PART: GENOCIDE, CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY
VI SPECIAL PART: AGGRESSION, OTHER CRIMES
VII NATIONAL COURTS, TRUTH AND RECONCILIATION COMMISSIONS
VIII INTERNATIONAL AND INTERNATIONALIZED CRIMINAL COURTS
X ICL AND WORLD POLITICS, PEACE vs JUSTICE

audience.et: Master’s students of International Law and Human Rights, but other master’s students are also welcome depending on certain limitations
